title: Build a Responsive Landing Page for a SaaS App
problemStatement: A startup is launching 'ZenFlow,' a new productivity app. They need a compelling, single-page website to explain the product, attract early adopters, and collect email sign-ups before launch.

milestones.title: Milestone 1: Create the HTML Structure
milestones.goal: Build the foundational HTML document with semantic tags for all the necessary sections of the landing page.
milestones.instructions: Create an `index.html` file. Use `<header>`, `<main>`, `<section>`, and `<footer>` tags. Include a heading for the product, a paragraph for the description, and a form with an email input and a submit button.

milestones.title: Milestone 2: Style with CSS
milestones.goal: Apply styling to make the page visually appealing and professional, using a mobile-first approach.
milestones.instructions: Create a `style.css` file. Style the page for a mobile screen first (single-column layout). Use Flexbox for alignment. Add colors and fonts. Then, use a media query (`@media (min-width: 768px)`) to adjust the layout for larger screens.

milestones.title: Milestone 3: Add Basic Interaction
milestones.goal: Use JavaScript to make the email sign-up form provide feedback to the user upon submission.
milestones.instructions: Create a `script.js` file. Write a JavaScript function that listens for the form's 'submit' event. Prevent the default page reload and show an alert or a 'Thank you' message to the user.

reflectionQuiz.question: Why is using semantic HTML tags like `<header>` and `<main>` important for SEO and accessibility?
What is the purpose of `event.preventDefault()` in your JavaScript code?

resumeText: Designed and developed a fully responsive landing page for a conceptual SaaS product, focusing on UI/UX principles and a mobile-first CSS approach while implementing interactive form validation with JavaScript.

title: Analyze E-commerce Customer Behavior
problemStatement: An online retail store, 'StyleSpree,' wants to understand its customers better. They've provided a sales dataset and want to know who their most valuable customers are, what their most popular products are, and when the peak shopping times are.

milestones.title: Milestone 1: Load and Clean the Dataset
milestones.goal: Prepare the provided dataset for analysis by handling missing values and correcting data types.
milestones.instructions: Use the Pandas library to load the CSV. Identify columns with missing data and decide on a strategy (e.g., fill with mean, drop rows). Ensure the 'OrderDate' column is converted to a proper datetime format.

milestones.title: Milestone 2: Identify Valuable Customers & Products
milestones.goal: Segment customers by total spending and identify the best-selling products by quantity.
milestones.instructions: Group the cleaned data by 'CustomerID' to calculate total spending. Then, group by 'SKU' to find the total quantity sold for each product. Present the top 5 of each.

milestones.title: Milestone 3: Visualize Sales Trends
milestones.goal: Create charts to visualize your findings about top products and peak shopping hours.
milestones.instructions: Using Matplotlib or Seaborn, create a bar chart for the top 5 best-selling products. Create another chart (e.g., a bar chart or line chart) showing the number of orders per hour of the day.

reflectionQuiz.question: What business decision could the company make based on your 'peak shopping hours' analysis?
Which Python library is primarily used for creating plots and charts?

resumeText: Analyzed an e-commerce sales dataset using Python (Pandas) to identify key business insights, including top-performing products and peak shopping hours, presenting findings in a summary report with visualizations (Matplotlib/Seaborn).

title: Design a Mobile App Onboarding Flow
problemStatement: A new fitness tracking app, 'FitPath,' is experiencing a high user drop-off rate after the initial download. Users are confused and don't complete the setup process. The goal is to design a clear, engaging, and efficient onboarding experience.

milestones.title: Milestone 1: Map the User Flow
milestones.goal: Create a simple diagram that outlines the steps a new user will take from opening the app for the first time to reaching the main dashboard.
milestones.instructions: Using a tool like Miro or even just pen and paper, create a flowchart. It should include screens for welcome, goal selection, notification permissions, and completion. Upload a screenshot of your diagram.

milestones.title: Milestone 2: Design Low-Fidelity Wireframes
milestones.goal: Create black-and-white, basic layouts for each screen in your user flow to focus on structure and content placement.
milestones.instructions: In Figma or a similar tool, design the wireframes for the 3-4 key onboarding screens. Don't worry about colors or fonts yet. Focus on buttons, text, and input fields. Export the screens as a single image or PDF.

milestones.title: Milestone 3: Build a High-Fidelity Clickable Prototype
milestones.goal: Add color, typography, and images to your wireframes, and then link them together to create a working prototype.
milestones.instructions: Develop your wireframes into full-color mockups. Use Figma's 'Prototype' mode to connect the 'Next' buttons on each screen so a user can click through the entire flow. Share the public Figma prototype link.

reflectionQuiz.question: Why is it important to start with low-fidelity wireframes before moving to high-fidelity designs?
What is the primary goal of a user onboarding experience?

resources.title: Nielsen Norman Group - Onboarding Best Practices

resumeText: Designed a 4-screen user onboarding flow for a conceptual mobile app, creating low-fidelity wireframes and a high-fidelity clickable prototype in Figma to improve user retention and simplify initial setup.

title: Create a Social Media Content Calendar
problemStatement: 'TerraBrew,' a new sustainable coffee brand, needs a content plan for their Instagram launch. The goal is to build brand awareness and create an engaged community.

milestones.title: Milestone 1: Define Strategy & Content Pillars
milestones.goal: Define the target audience and establish 3-4 core content themes (pillars) that will guide your posts.
milestones.instructions: In a text document, describe the target audience (e.g., 'Eco-conscious millennials, aged 25-35'). Define 3 content pillars like 'Product Spotlights,' 'Sustainability Facts,' and 'User-Generated Content.'

milestones.title: Milestone 2: Build a 2-Week Content Calendar
milestones.goal: Create a structured calendar planning out posts for the first two weeks of the campaign.
milestones.instructions: Using a spreadsheet (Google Sheets, Excel), create columns for: Date, Content Pillar, Post Idea/Caption, and Visual Idea (e.g., 'Photo of our packaging'). Plan at least 5 posts.

milestones.title: Milestone 3: Design Sample Posts
milestones.goal: Create mockups for three of the posts from your content calendar to show what they would look like on Instagram.
milestones.instructions: Using a tool like Canva, create three sample Instagram posts. Write compelling captions and choose relevant hashtags for each. Combine them into a single PDF or image for submission.

reflectionQuiz.question: Why is it important to have different 'content pillars' instead of just posting about the product?
What is the role of hashtags in an Instagram strategy?

resources.title: HubSpot - How to Create a Social Media Calendar

resumeText: Developed a comprehensive social media content strategy for a new brand launch, defining a target audience and content pillars, and creating a two-week content calendar with sample post mockups.

title: Predict Customer Churn with Machine Learning
problemStatement: A telecom company wants to proactively identify customers who are likely to churn (cancel their service). Using a dataset of customer information, your task is to build a machine learning model that can predict churn with a high degree of accuracy.

milestones.title: Milestone 1: Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA)
milestones.goal: Load the data, clean it, and perform initial analysis to understand the dataset's characteristics and find basic correlations with churn.
milestones.instructions: Load the dataset and handle missing values. Convert categorical columns (like 'Contract') into numerical format using one-hot encoding. Create a few basic plots to visualize the data, like a count plot of the 'Churn' column.

milestones.title: Milestone 2: Train a Classification Model
milestones.goal: Split the data and train a machine learning model, such as Logistic Regression or Random Forest, to predict the 'Churn' variable.
milestones.instructions: Split your preprocessed data into training and testing sets using `train_test_split`. Initialize and train a `RandomForestClassifier` model on the training data.

milestones.title: Milestone 3: Evaluate Model Performance
milestones.goal: Use your trained model to make predictions on the test set and evaluate its performance using key classification metrics.
milestones.instructions: Use your trained model to predict churn on `X_test`. Calculate and report the model's accuracy, precision, and recall using functions from Scikit-Learn. Briefly explain what each metric means in the context of this problem.

reflectionQuiz.question: In this problem, would you prioritize higher Precision or higher Recall? Why?
What does 'Feature Engineering' mean in the context of machine learning?

resumeText: Developed a machine learning model to predict customer churn using Python (Pandas, Scikit-Learn), achieving high accuracy by training and evaluating a Random Forest classifier and identifying key predictive features.

title: Create a Personal Budgeting Spreadsheet
problemStatement: A recent graduate wants to get better control of their finances. They need a simple but effective spreadsheet to track their monthly income and expenses, and to see where their money is going.

milestones.title: Milestone 1: Set Up an Expense Log
milestones.goal: Create a structured table to log individual income and expense transactions.
milestones.instructions: In a spreadsheet, create a sheet named 'Log'. Create columns for 'Date', 'Description', 'Category' (e.g., 'Food', 'Rent', 'Income'), and 'Amount'. Add at least 10 sample expense/income entries.

milestones.title: Milestone 2: Build a Monthly Summary Dashboard
milestones.goal: Create a new sheet that automatically summarizes the data from the 'Log' sheet by category.
milestones.instructions: Create a new sheet named 'Dashboard'. Use the `SUMIF` function to automatically calculate the total spending for each category (e.g., `=SUMIF(Log!C:C, "Food", Log!D:D)`). Create a summary for Total Income, Total Expenses, and Net Savings (Income - Expenses).

milestones.title: Milestone 3: Visualize Spending
milestones.goal: Create a pie chart on the 'Dashboard' sheet that visually represents the proportion of spending in each category.
milestones.instructions: Using the summary data you created in Milestone 2, insert a Pie Chart. The chart should show what percentage of your total expenses goes towards each category. Give the chart a clear title.

reflectionQuiz.question: What is the benefit of using a function like `SUMIF` instead of manually adding up the numbers?
What insight can you gain from a pie chart that you can't easily see from a table of numbers?

resources.title: How to Make a Pie Chart in Google Sheets

resumeText: Designed and built a dynamic personal budgeting tool using spreadsheet software (Google Sheets/Excel), employing functions like SUMIF to automate financial tracking and creating data visualizations to analyze spending habits.
